descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses

But at least #capitalism and markets ensure "efficient" production and allocation of resources.

Sure, some may starve, but only the least deserving. See, "deserving" is determined by wealth. Those with less wealth deserve less of the bounties of this earth.

Which is the same logic behind "efficiency" (according to economists) which is defined largely based on willingness to pay for goods.

I wish that was sarcasm, or a joke. Clearly, this is not a just system.

#economics

account.note:
I'm an environmental economist who researches econ pedagogy to make learning economics marginally less dismal.

My pipe-dream is to write a fantasy novel/economics textbook, which is getting closer to reality every day.

#economics #TeachEcon #sustainability #DoughnutEconomics #degrowth

Profile pic is me smiling in front of a whiteboard with economics gibberish -- cause econ makes me happy.

Background is my dog, Freya, who is derpily sticking her tongue out while passed out.

fields.name: About me
fields.value: Making econ marginally less dismal one post at a time. I teach economics at the UC Denver and am an all around nerd. My goal is to combine my passion for all things fantasy/sci-fi and love of economics to lower the cost of learning econ.

fields.name: Fantastical Economics
fields.value: You can find my first-ever short story that covers the circular economy and sustainability in a sci-fi setting here: https://edgeryders.eu/t/circular-reasoning/19717

descendants.content:
> "Sure, some may starve, but only the least deserving. See, "deserving" is determined by wealth. Those with less wealth deserve less of the bounties of this earth."

@FantasticalEconomics very well said.

Neoliberals believe capitalism is a system where people who produce more value to society, people who work harder and work smarter, deserve to be, and are generally are, rewarded more by "the market." What isn't stated is that what "produces value" is not only completely arbitrary, but decided entirely by people who are already in a position of political and economic power, the people who control "the market" because they have such vast wealth. In other words, the politically powerful have the right to arbitrarily decide who is blessed as "producers of value," and therefore who is deserves to live. Capitalism is just this incredibly cruel and hateful form of totalitarianism obscured behind a facade of "work harder/smarter to earn more."

@breadandcircuses

account.note: I'm just some kind of nerd: software developer, big fan of functional programming, especially Haskell and Scheme. I also love old Macintosh computers. You could call me a "full stack" engineer, but server-side is where I am really in my element.

descendants.content:
> "Under real totalitarianism, I'd be rounded up as a dissenter years ago. This discussion would be enough to jail someone in North Korea."

@HumanServitor sounds to me like you believe everything is either totalitarian or freedom with no shades of gray in between.

There are much more subtle forms of control than what you see in North Korea. As in propaganda in all forms of media. As in deliberate cruelty to the poor to make the middle classes scared to death of quitting their job or even demanding better pay or safer work conditions. As in legalizing slave labor for felons then criminalizing recreation (e.g. doing drugs) so you have an always-available source of felons/slaves. This is also totalitarianism, just not as obvious or extreme as what North Korean authorities do to dissenters.

Though sometimes the totalitarian nature of capitalism is not so subtle. For example if you try to protest the genocide of Gaza, try to protest any war at all, try to protest an oil pipeline, try to protest police brutality. Then you get a more thorough totalitarian treatment: beaten up by cops and thrown in jail (if only temporarily) for no reason at all, sometimes even shot to death in the street, even though protesting is supposed to be legal. And day by day, the countries of the English-speaking world are gradually becoming more and more totalitarian, as the ultra-wealthy gather more and more wealth and eliminate more and more laws and regulations that could keeping them from becoming total despots.

Solutions ? There aren't any... All we can do is endure until it falls apart. Perhaps then we'll realise money can't be eaten?

card.title: The Grab | A Magnolia Pictures Film | Directed by Gabriela Cowperthwaite | Now in Theaters and on Digital
card.description: Quietly and seemingly out of sight, governments, private investors and mercenaries are working to seize food and water resources at the expense of entire populations. These groups are establishing themselves as the new OPEC, where the future world powers will be those who control not oil, but food.

descendants.content: @breadandcircuses Keeping food under lock and key is a fundamental pillar of our culture. It has been used as an instrument of control, expansion and wealth accumulation. Many systems have used it, monarchies, feuds, communism, capitalism. The latter has only converted this tool of control into another product to squeeze out more capital, not for the sake of feeding people, but for the sake of more capital.
